The '''triple helix model of innovation''' refers to a set of interactions between academia, industry and governments, to foster economic and social development.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=11 July 2011|title=The Triple Helix Concept|url=https://triplehelix.stanford.edu/3helix_concept|journal=Stanford University Triple Helix Research Group|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.leydesdorff.net/arist09/arist09.pdf|title=The Knowledge-Based Economy and the Triple Helix Model|last=Leydesdorff|first=Loet|date=|website=University of Amsterdam, Amsterdam School of Communications Research|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> This framework was first theorized by Henry Etzkowitz and [[Loet Leydesdorff]] in the 1990s, with the publication of “The Triple Helix, University-Industry-Government Relations: A laboratory for Knowledge-Based Economic Development”.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Etzkowitz|first=Henry|last2=Leydesdorff|first2=Loet|date=1995-01-01|title=The Triple Helix -- University-Industry-Government Relations: A Laboratory for Knowledge Based Economic Development|url=https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=2480085|location=Rochester, NY}}</ref> Interactions between universities, industries and governments have given rise to new intermediary institutions, such as [[University technology transfer offices|technology transfer offices]] and [[science park]]s.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/c737/7b7a3c21d78caff9357560da79064ea197b5.pdf|title=University-Industry-Government: The Triple Helix Model of Innovation|last=Etzkowitz|first=Henry|date=|website=Newcastle University Business School|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The triple helix also participated in the transformation of each institution.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=The triple helix : university-industry-government innovation in action|last=1940-|first=Etzkowitz, Henry|date=2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415964500|location=New York|oclc=173749026}}</ref>
== Three components of the model == The triple helix model of innovation, as theorized by Etzkowitz and Leydesdorff, is based on the interactions between the three following elements and their associated ‘initial role’:<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.leydesdorff.net/th11/th11.pdf|title=The Triple Helix in the context of global change: dynamics and challenges|last=Leydesdorff, Loet; Lawton Smith, Helen|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> universities engaging in basic research, industries producing commercial goods and governments that are regulating markets.<ref name=":1" /> As interactions increase within this framework, each component evolves to adopt some characteristics of the other institution, which then gives rise to hybrid institutions. Bilateral interactions exist between university, industry and government.
=== University-industry interactions ===
Etzkowitz and Leydesdorff argue that the initial role of universities is to provide education to individuals and basic research. Therefore, interactions between university and industry revolve initially around those two elements. In a [[linear model of innovation]], universities are supposed to provide the research on which industry will build upon to produce commercial goods. The other interactions take place through the involvement of industry managers and university faculty in both sectors. According to Etzkowitz, the transfer of people between university and industry constitutes a very important transfer of knowledge. This can be a permanent move in one direction or the other, or in other cases, entire careers spent between the two spheres. He gives the example of [[Carl Djerassi]], a research director for a pharmaceutical company who joined Stanford University while continuing his industrial activity.<ref name=":1" />
However, other scholars have pointed out that consulting activities of faculty members could also have drawbacks, like a reduced focus on educating the students, and potential conflict of interests relating to the use of university resources for the benefit of industry.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Boyer|first=Carol M.|last2=Lewis|first2=Darrell R.|date=1984|title=Faculty Consulting: Responsibility or Promiscuity?|jstor=1981827|journal=The Journal of Higher Education|volume=55|issue=5|pages=637–659|doi=10.2307/1981827}}</ref> Additional transfer of knowledge between university and industry happens through informal communication, conferences or industrial interest in university publications.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Sampat|first=Bhaven N.|title=Patenting and US academic research in the 20th century: The world before and after Bayh-Dole|journal=Research Policy|volume=35|issue=6|pages=772–789|doi=10.1016/j.respol.2006.04.009|year=2006}}</ref> Another type of interaction, for example, is the creation of co-op programs like the MIT-General Electric course<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carlson|first=W. Bernard|date=1988|title=Academic Entrepreneurship and Engineering Education: Dugald C. Jackson and the MIT-GE Cooperative Engineering Course, 1907-1932|jstor=3105273|journal=Technology and Culture|volume=29|issue=3|pages=536–567|doi=10.2307/3105273}}</ref> which aims at integrating an industry approach into the students' curricula.
=== University-government interactions ===
The strength of the interactions between the government and universities depends on the government’s general relationship to and policy towards higher education. Etzkowitz and Leydesdorff's model uses a spectrum to define the extent of these interactions. On the one hand, when higher education is largely public, as in continental western Europe, the government has a higher influence on universities and the research they conduct by being the main source of funding.<ref name=":2" /> On the other hand of the spectrum, typically associated with the United States, universities have a higher degree of independence from government influence although they also receive funding. However, the two ends of this spectrum are used as ideal-types that are not necessarily reflective of the reality.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Etzkowitz|first=Henry|date=2002-2011|title=The Triple Helix of University - Industry - Government Implications for Policy and Evaluation|url=http://www.sister.nu/pdf/wp_11.pdf|journal=Institutet för Studier av Utbildning och Forskning|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The changing circumstances can push the government to create closer ties with academia, for example in wartime, and/or through funding of strategic disciplines, like physics. For example, in the United States, the [[Ministry of Defence|Department of Defense]] has extensively funded physics research during [[World War II]] and the [[Cold War]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=acls;idno=heb00988.0001.001|title=The Cold War and American science: the military-industrial-academic complex at MIT and Stanford|last=Leslie|first=Stuart W.|date=1993|publisher=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Another example of state involvement in higher education is the establishment of new universities, as through the [[Morrill Land-Grant Acts]] of 1862 encouraging the creation of [[Land-grant university|land-grant colleges]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kargon|first=Robert H.|last2=Knowles|first2=Scott G.|date=2002-01-01|title=Knowledge for Use: Science, Higher Learning, and America's New Industrial Heartland, 1880-1915|journal=Annals of Science|volume=59|issue=1|pages=1–20|doi=10.1080/00033790010028188|issn=0003-3790}}</ref> [[Cornell University]], the [[University of Florida]] and [[Purdue University]] are three of the seventy-six institutions created under the land-grant.
=== Government-industry interactions ===
The relationship between governments and industry depends on the government’s attitude towards the market. In liberal economies the role of the government will be limited to preventing market failures. On the other hand, where the government is more involved in the economy, the government’s role is the regulation of the industry. These are also two ends of a spectrum, leaving room for substantial variation, based on circumstances and disciplines.<ref name=":2" /> For example, as pointed out by Bhaven Sampat, in the 1960s, the government created a regulation to prevent patenting by or licensing to industry of university research funded by the [[National Institutes of Health]].<ref name=":3" /> One key role of the government in its interaction with industry is the establishment of intellectual property law and its enforcement.
=== Strength of interaction === Etzkowitz and Leydesdorff initially argued that the strength of the interactions between governments, industry and university depends on which component is the driving force in the framework. In a statist model, a strong state is driving interactions between the three components in a top-down implementation.<ref name=":5" /> It creates stronger ties and a more integrated model. In a laissez-faire model, in which the industry and market forces are the leading forces, the ties are weaker and each institution tends to remain very independent. However, the distinction between the two models is not always clear cut, as the government can choose to adopt a strong or a weak stance depending on the context and the industry.<ref name=":2" /> In a recent paper, Etzkowitz emphasized that the shift towards a knowledge-based society has given a bigger role to universities. Indeed, as innovation is increasingly based on scientific knowledge, the role of universities as creators of knowledge is more valued.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Etzkowitz|first=Henry|date=2003-09-01|title=Innovation in Innovation: The Triple Helix of University-Industry-Government Relations|journal=Social Science Information|language=en|volume=42|issue=3|pages=293–337|doi=10.1177/05390184030423002|issn=0539-0184}}</ref> As a result, he argues that university, industry and government are more equal,<ref name=":4" /> and that no particular element is necessarily the driving force of the triple helix model of innovation.
== Evolution and hybridization == The triple helix model of innovation also blurred the boundaries of the traditional basic roles of university, industry and government. According to Etzkowitz and Leydesdorff, this marks the second step in the triple helix of innovation framework.<ref name=":6" /> For example, universities increasingly take part in commercial activity through patenting and licensing, moving beyond the production of basic research. The next step is the emergence of intermediaries between the three elements as well as the hybridization of the three entities.<ref name=":0" /> Nevertheless, each entity retains a strong primacy in its original field of expertise: the university remains the main source of knowledge production, industry is the primary vehicle of commercialization and the government retains its regulatory role.
Technology transfer offices have been established by universities to foster the transformation of university basic or applied research with a commercial value into commercial goods. One of the aims of TTOs is to create some revenues for the university, thus enhancing its role as an economic actor. However, the average profitability of TTOs remains very low.<ref name=":3" /> For example, the revenues earned through the licensing of patents by TTOs in American universities are, on average, ten times larger than for European TTOs according to the Innovation Policy Platform.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.innovationpolicyplatform.org/sites/default/files/rdf_imported_documents/TechnologyTransferOffices.pdf|title=Technology transfer offices - Policy Brief|last=|first=|date=|website=Innovation Policy Platform|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Science parks have also emerged as the result of the collaboration of industries and universities with the government.<ref name=":4" /> They can stem from the initiative of an industrial region to modernize itself with the impulse of a university. On the other hand, they can be the result of a university initiative to attract industry, as was the case with the development of [[Stanford University|Stanford]]'s science park around the university or the [[Research Triangle Park|Research Triangle]] in North Carolina.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Leslie|first=Stuart W.|last2=Kargon|first2=Robert H.|date=1996|title=Selling Silicon Valley: Frederick Terman's Model for Regional Advantage|jstor=3117312|journal=The Business History Review|volume=70|issue=4|pages=435–472|doi=10.2307/3117312}}</ref>
The 'entrepreneurial university' is another hybrid element which Etzkowitz defines around the following elements : the capitalization of knowledge, strong ties with industry and governments, a high degree of independence, and permanent evolution of the relationships between universities, industry and government. Etzkowitz recognizes [[MIT]] as a great example of an 'entrepreneurial university’.<ref name=":2" />
== Quadruple helix model ==
Building on the triple helix model, the quadruple helix model adds a fourth component to the framework of interactions between university, industry and government: civil society and the media.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cavallini, Simona; Soldi, Rossella; Friedl, Julia; Volpe, Margherita|date=2016|title=Using the Quadruple Helix Approach to Accelerate the Transfer of Research and Innovation Results to Regional Growth|url=http://cor.europa.eu/en/documentation/studies/Documents/quadruple-helix.pdf|journal=European Union Committee of the Regions|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> It was first suggested by Elias G. Carayannis and David F.J. Campbell in "‘Mode 3’ and ‘Quadruple Helix’: toward a 21st century fractal innovation ecosystem".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carayannis, E.G. and Campbell, D.F.J.|date=2009|title='Mode 3' and 'Quadruple Helix': toward a 21st century fractal innovation ecosystem|url=https://edisciplinas.usp.br/pluginfile.php/3572572/mod_resource/content/1/8-carayannis2009.pdf|journal=Int. J. Technology Management|volume= 46| issue = 3/4|pages=201–234|via=}}</ref> The aim is to bridge the gaps between innovation and civil society. Indeed, this framework claims that under the triple helix model, the emerging technologies do not always match the demands and needs of society, thus limiting their potential impact. This framework emphasizes a societal responsibility of universities, in addition to their role of educating and conduction research. This is the approach that the [[European Union]] has intended to take for the development of a competitive knowledge-based society.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cresson|first=Edith|date=17 November 1997|title=Towards a Knowledge-based Europe. Lecture by Mrs Edith Cresson at the London School of Economics and Political Science|url=|journal=|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The quadruple helix model has been argued to include both the civil society and the users of innovation. How to define this fourth helix has been debated according to Högluind and Linton (2018)<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Höglund|first=Linda|last2=Linton|first2=Gabriel|date=2017-12-27|title=Smart specialization in regional innovation systems: a quadruple helix perspective|journal=R&D Management|language=en|volume=48|issue=1|pages=60–72|doi=10.1111/radm.12306|issn=0033-6807}}</ref> and some researchers see it as an additional helix while some see it as a different type of helix which is overarching all the other helices.<ref name=":7" />
== Triple helix and policy making == The triple helix model has been used as a lens through which evolving relationships between university, industry and government can be analyzed. But according to Etzkowitz and Leydesdorff, it can also be a policy making tool. For example, Etzkowitz argues that after the end of the Soviet Era, triple helix inspired policies were implemented in Eastern Europe to promote their growth. In Sweden, the triple helix policy aimed at tying together innovation initiatives at different scales to increase their overall efficiency.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" /> They emphasize the relevance of implementing the triple helix model for developing countries and regions.
=== Criticism of the model ===
The triple helix model as a policy-making tool for economic growth and regional development has been criticized by many scholars. One main criticism is that Etzkowitz and Leydesdorff’s framework was developed within Western developed countries, which means that it is based on a particular set of infrastructures and under circumstances. For instance, the model take for granted that knowledge intensive activities are linked to economic growth, that intellectual property rights will be protected, and that the state has a democratic and market oriented culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.triplehelixconference.org/th/11/bic/docs/Papers/Cai.pdf|title=Enhancing context sensitivity of the Triple Helix model: An institutional logics perspective|last=Yuzhuo Cai|date=10 July 2013|website=Triple Helix Conference|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Therefore, according to critics, the triple helix model is not a relevant policy making tool for developing countries where at least one of these conditions is missing. Further scholarly criticism of the model focuses on the conditions that enable the implementation of a triple helix innovation policy. It argues that Etzkowitz and Leydesdorff’s model is too vague and take for granted those necessary preconditions within their model.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.triplehelixassociation.org/helice/volume-4-2015/helice-issue-4/triple-helix-scientific-news/enabling-conditions-for-regional-triple-helix-systems|title=Enabling conditions for regional triple helix systems|last=Cai, Yuzhuo; Ough, Rihannon; Liu, Cui|date=|website=Triple Helix Association|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Williams|first=Logan D. A.|last2=Woodson|first2=Thomas S.|date=2012|title=The Future of Innovation Studies in Less Economically Developed Countries|jstor=43548641|journal=Minerva|volume=50|issue=2|pages=221–237|doi=10.2307/43548641|doi-broken-date=2018-11-04}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox MP |honorific-prefix = |name = William Barber |honorific-suffix = |image = William Henry Peter Barber.jpg |alt = |caption = |constituency_MP4 = [[Newtown (New Zealand electorate)|Newtown]] |parliament4 = New Zealand |term_start4 = 1902 |term_end4 = 1908 |predecessor4 = new electorate |successor4 = electorate abolished |office5 = [[Wellington City Council]]lor |term_start5 = 1891 |term_end5 = 1905 |term_start6 = 1910 |term_end6 = 1919 |birth_date = 10 September 1857 |birth_place = [[Wellington]], New Zealand |death_date = 15 January 1943 |death_place = [[Wellington]], New Zealand |restingplace = |restingplacecoordinates = |birthname = |nationality = |party = [[New Zealand Liberal Party|Liberal]] |otherparty = [[New Liberal Party (New Zealand)|New Liberal Party]] |spouse = Emily Clarke |relations = |children = 5 |alma_mater = |profession = |religion = |signature = }} '''William Henry Peter Barber''' (10 September 1857 – 15 January 1943) was a New Zealand [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Newtown (New Zealand electorate)|Newtown]] in [[Wellington]].
==Early life and family== Born in Wellington in 1857, Barber was educated at St Peter's School. He began work in his father's dyeing firm of Barber and Company, and eventually became its head. He married Emily Clarke, of Somerset, England in 1879, and had three sons and two daughters.<ref name="EP obit">{{cite news|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19430115.2.26 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|Evening Post]] |volume=CXXXV|issue=12|date=15 January 1943|page=3|title=Obituary Mr. W.H.P. Barber|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref>
==Member of Parliament== {{NZ parlbox header|nolist=true|align=left}} {{NZ parlbox |start={{NZ election link year|1902}} |end=1905 |term=15th |electorate={{NZ electorate link|Newtown}} |party=New Zealand Liberal Party }} {{NZ parlbox allegiance |start=1905 |end= |party=New Liberal Party (New Zealand) }} {{NZ parlbox |start={{NZ election link year|1905}} |end=1908 |term=16th |electorate=Newtown |party=New Zealand Liberal Party }} {{end}} William Barber represented the [[Wellington]] electorate of [[Newtown (New Zealand electorate)|Newtown]] for the whole of its existence, from [[New Zealand general election, 1902|1902]] to 1908. In [[New Zealand general election, 1908|1908]] he was defeated for the reconstituted electorate of [[Wellington South (New Zealand electorate)|Wellington South]].
===New Liberal Party=== Barber was associated with the [[New Liberal Party (New Zealand)|New Liberal Party]]. His favourite idea was one shared by the other New Liberals-that the institutions of local government should be strengthened and given more scope and power. He heartily supported [[Harry Ell]]'s 1904 Municipal Corporations Bill, which provided for borough councils to hold referenda.<ref>{{citation |journal = New Zealand Parliamentary Debates |volume = 123 |pages = 372}}</ref>
Barber also advocated state fire insurance, state coal mines, and the old radical favourite, reduction of taxes on the necessities of life. However, he did not favour the elective executive.<ref>{{citation |journal = New Zealand Times |date = 24 November 1902|page=7}}</ref>
==Other activities== He served as a director of the Wellington Woollen Company (chairman at the time of his death), and chairman of directors of the Wellington Opera House Company. He was elected to the [[Wellington City Council]] in 1891 and served as a councilor for 26 years.<ref name="EP obit" /> He contested the [[Wellington City mayoral election, 1905|1905 Wellington City mayoral election]] and came second, beaten by [[Thomas William Hislop]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=NZFL19050429.2.19.1 |work = The Free Lance |page=16 |title=Wellington City Council |date= 29 April 1905 |accessdate= 15 March 2016 | volume=V | issue=43 }}</ref> He was a member of the Hutt Valley Electric Power Board (retired 1933); director of Wellington Deposit and Mortgage Company; chairman of the Wellington College Board of Governors (1924–31) and a member of the Kauri Timber Royal Commission.<ref name="EP obit"/>
In 1935, he was awarded the [[King George V Silver Jubilee Medal]].<ref name="EP">{{cite news | url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19350506.2.12 | title=Official jubilee medals | date=6 May 1935 | newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] | accessdate=2 July 2013 | page=4}}</ref>
==Death== Barber died in Wellington on 15 January 1943,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19430115.2.4 | title=Deaths | date=15 January 1943 | work=Evening Post | accessdate=27 March 2016 | page=1}}</ref> and was buried at [[Karori Cemetery]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wellington.govt.nz/services/community-and-culture/cemeteries/cemeteries-search/details?id=30328&serviceType=Burial |title=Cemeteries search |date= |website= |publisher=Wellington City Council |accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref>
